>>\(\rho\) is called the utilization of the system because \(\rho\):<<
( ) Is composed of the fraction of \(\mu\) over \(\lambda\), and therefore represents the fraction of time that the system is idle.
( ) Quantifies how much capacity a system has.
(x) Is composed of the fraction of \(\lambda\) over \(\mu\), and therefore represents the fraction of time that the system is busy.
( ) Is the maximum rate of flow the system can handle.
[explanation] Recall that \( \rho = \frac{\lambda} {\mu} = \frac{average ~service ~time}{average ~inter-arrival ~time}\). In other words, the \(\rho\) represents the fraction of time the system is servicing over the average time between customers arrivals (see video 2 on slide 72).
